content: The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1995" amends Section 599 of title 28, United States Code, and provides a basis for preliminary investigation. The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1995" amends Section 591 of title 28, United States Code, by specifying credible sources for specific information and removing language suggesting possibility. The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1995" amends Section 591 of title 28, United States Code by specifying credible sources for information and setting a 15-day time period for the Attorney General to determine the need for a preliminary investigation. The Attorney General must commence a preliminary investigation if there is sufficient evidence of a violation within a 15-day period. Section 592(c)(2) of title 28, United States Code is amended to require specific information from a credible source. SEC. 4. PROSECUTORIAL JURISDICTION OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. Prosecutorial jurisdiction under title 28, United States Code, is amended to specify limitations to alleged criminal law violations and related matters when the Attorney General requests the appointment of an independent counsel. The amendment to title 28, United States Code, specifies the independent counsel's prosecutorial jurisdiction to fully investigate and prosecute alleged criminal law violations, including perjury, obstruction of justice, destruction of evidence, and intimidation of witnesses. Amendment to title 28, United States Code clarifies the independent counsel's jurisdiction to investigate and prosecute criminal law violations, including perjury, obstruction of justice, destruction of evidence, and witness intimidation. Section 592(d) is amended to specify the scope of criminal violations and related matters. The independent counsel is granted authorities and duties under Section 5. The independent counsel is granted authorities and duties under Section 5. Amendments are made regarding office space provision and compliance with Department of Justice policies. The independent counsel's authorities and duties are amended, including provisions for office space and compliance with Department of Justice policies. Section 594 of title 28, United States Code is further amended to include limitations on expenditures. Limitation on Expenditures: No funds can be used for an independent counsel's office after 2 years unless specified in a later appropriations Act. SEC. 6. REMOVAL, TERMINATION, AND PERIODIC REAPPOINTMENT OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. Amendment to title 28, United States Code allows for the removal of an independent counsel for failure to comply with Department of Justice policies or specific sections. The court division has the authority to terminate an independent counsel's office at any time. The Amendment to title 28, United States Code allows for the removal of an independent counsel on various grounds, including completion of the investigation or at the request of the Attorney General. The independent counsel can be removed based on the completion of the investigation or if it is not in the public interest. Monthly expenditures must be reported to specified committees. The independent counsel must apply for reappointment every 2 years, and the court will decide if the counsel should continue or be terminated. The court will reappoint the independent counsel if it decides not to terminate the office, or appoint another qualified person if necessary. If the court fails to take action within 90 days after the 2-year period, the office of independent counsel will terminate. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within 1 year of this Act's enactment, with recommendations to improve cost controls for independent counsel offices under chapter 40 of title 28, United States Code.
